Committee Pleased With Results of Two
Weeks' Work on Dormitory Fund.
Building Probable Next Year.

Big Mass Meeting Addressed by Dr.
Goodnow—Mr. B. H. Griswold and
Capt. Wardlow Miles Quick to

Two weeks of the dormitory
campaign have passed, just half
of the time in which it was
thought the money could be raised.
The committee in charge of the
drive thinks its efforts have been
well rewarded, but it has not yet
received enough subscriptions to
be able to .predict easy going.

With enthusiasm at a high
pitch, the undergraduate classes_
showed what they thought of the
new dorthitory by pledging $14,500
toward the fund at a huge massmeeting held last Wednesday.
The meeting was opened in the
Civil Engineering Hall, at 12.30

The Black and Blue gridders
retrievel their defeat at the
hands of Haverford by administering a severe trouncing to the
Western Maryland aggregation at
Honiewood last Saturday, coming
off the field with the score of 30-6.
The old punch was back in the
team again, and Hopkins played
the up staters off their feet from
start lo finish. Capt. Elmer Jones
was back in his old form, playieg
the best game he has shown since
he was hurt at Navy. He bucked
the line for gains time and again,
when a few yards were needed,
and broke away toward the end of
the fourth period for a 70-yard
run and touchdown. Hoffman
also starred for the Black and
Blue, skirting tackle and end for
gains of 7 to 20 yards time after
time. He completed a forward
pass to "Bill" Wood, which netted
21 yards, and Jones carried the
ball across the goal line for the
third touchdown on the next play.
The entire Black and Blue line,
and especially Lardy and Egerton, tore through the Western
Maryland line, nabbincr the runplay.

the preachers, the former being
the only man who was able to advance the ball against the sterling
Black and Blue line. "Pop" Langrail received a forward pass from
Collins on his 25-yard line and
ran the length of the field for a
touchdown, saving the Methodists
from a shut-out.
Hopkins started off like a whirlwind, scoring the first touchdown
within four minutes• of play and
following it immediately after
with another. Barrett kicked off

same hole. Pullen hit right guard
for 2 brace of yards and Kinsey
made it first down. This was the
only first down the visitors were
able to annex until the last period. On the next play, Kinsey
fumbled and Hoffman fell on the
lall on the 50-yard line. Then began a march down the field. Jones
plunged through right guard for
six yards. -Western Maryland was
penalized live yards for offside and

to be called back, as Hopkins was

With but three weeks remaining
before the first concert, the Musical Clubs have quickened their
stride and are swinging along at
double time. Thus far practices
have been held on Monday evenings, but beginning with Thursday the twentieth, rehearsals will
be held regularly on both Mondays and Thursdays at 8 P. M.
The attendance of the men who
hope to win a place on the clubs
for the concerts has been exceptionally good, due to the keen interest shown by all, as well as to
the realization that the next three
or four weeks will determine just
• who will represent the University
in the winter and spring concerts.
•
George Cattanach, the president
of the clubs, wishes to express his
gratification with the enthusiasm
showy and with the large number
of men who have indicated their
intention to win a place on one
of the clubs. Over fifty men signed
up, a good number from which to
.select the personnel proper, but
since the first two or three rehearsals a few men have dropped out.
These men are under classmen,
mostly freshmen, and the president cannot let pass the opportunity of warning them against an
indifferent and lax attitude, or a
"what's the use feeling." The man
who makes good in the clubs (and
it is not by any means an easy
job) is the man who, when an
under-classman sticks loyally to
the work, attends the rehearsals
regularly and gradually fits himself for a permanent place later
on. The freshman, who for one
reason or another, puts off this
work is greatly lessening his
chances of ever making the clubs,
for only the interested man is
wanted — the directors have no
time for any others.
The music being used this year
is the very best popular college
music obtainable. The Glee Club
songs are new at Hopkins, as well
as unique, and should prevent the
audience from leaving the concerts dry-eyed. The Instrumental
Club, with its wonderful assortment of mandoling, mandolas,
guitars, steel guitars, ukuleles and
banjo likes, will be a novelty this
year. In addition to the regular
"line," there will be several surprises for the audience, an expert
buck-and-wing dancer and a comic
song artist, a jazz orchestra, the
original interpretation of the Hawaiian native dances by the interpreter herself, and a Hawaiian
string trio.
, Harry Hartman, director of the
Glee Club, selected the 'Varsity
quartet after a series of try-outs.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

NOV. 18, 1919

A Hop in Hopkins Athletics.

Anyone who regards Mr. Kistler as the director of a puppet
show would receive a distinct revision of opinion were he to visit
Straus Field or observe the activities of his squads in other
quarters. Here, instead of bands
of disgruntled youths, passing
three hours every week to the
count of one, two, three, four, we
find squads of young, coming athletes engaged in practicing every
form of athletics. Football, lacrosse, basket-ball and soccer all
have their devotees.
The "pep" and enthusiasm of
these junior athletes cannot be emphasized enough. Seldom have
there been more closely or more
hotly contested games than the
two which have already been
played between the two Notball
sqnads. Iu'these games teamwork
and headwork was displayed on
both sides to such an extent that
the victorious team won by the
slender margin of 'six points in
both games. This is only one example of the interest shown by
these men. Basket-ball has a great
number of followers, in fact so
many that a league of eight teams
has been organized. Soccer, although started only Thursday,
promises, from the number of candidates, to be a great success, and
a huge *squad has already been
practicing lacrosse for some
weeks.
The greatest drawback to the
athletic success of Johns Hopkins has been the scarcity of ma-

terial. The organization of junior
athletics will undoubtedly be of
inestimable value in doing away
with this drawback. By thus
stimulating an interest in *athletics a far larger number of men
to pick from can be obtained and
many stars who were otherwise
"born to blush unseen" , will be
brought to light. Here is where
the future quarterback and ends,
lacrosse and basket-ball players
will be procured. Indeed much
promising material has already
been developed and it is thought
that within another year or so
the junior athletes will furnish, a
reliable reserve for the senior
teams.

ZOOLOGICAL SEMINARY MEETS
Relation Between Biology and Sociology
is Subject for This Year—Two
Interesting Payers Read.

The Zoological Seminary consists of informal weekly meetings
of the instructors and graduate
'students from the Department of
Zoology, including a number of
individuals 'from other departments and schools. There is no
organization. All members share
equally in the resposibilities of
carrying on the work, although
Pra. H. S. Jennings usually assumes the role of guiding spirit.
The meetings are held in the evening, usually at the home of ProTHE NEWS-LETTER'S MAILBAG
fessor Jennings. They consist of
reading and informal discussion.

QUACKS FROM A QUACK
Gentlemen of the jury, I trust
that most of you were keen-witted
enough to appreciate the rare bits
of satire and humor with which I
so generously sprinkled my last
article. With this trust in my
heart, I beg to submit for your
approval tile following clippings
gathered from here, there and
everywhere.
Yours in sport,
•

GEORGE.
To whom it may concern (and
unless I miss my guess, it will
concern a. goodly number): Dr.
Hulburt announced that all those
who have difficulties, minor or
otherwise, with their math problems may,if the worst collies to the
worst, hand in a blank paper, and
they will receive five points for
their nerve. Time eminent Doctor
failed to state just what he intended to do with the unspoiled sheets,
but I'll bet you a last year's almanac that in these days of high
prices he won't throw them away.
Dame Rumor has it that a little
incident worthy of publicity was
enacted lately, with our dearly beloved Capt. Ehner Jones playing
the leading lady. Everybody, no
doubt, has noticed the hat of
emerald lino that has been seen
liii 111mg around the University
with Elmer underneath of it.
Well, Elmer was taking this ancient and honorable chapeau out
for a walk on the boulevard the
other day, when for some unknown reason a little maid who
was strolling by the wayside was
heard to remark: "Oh, look,
Nursie, is that the Kaiser?" How
about it, Elmer, do I get that
hat?—that old 'derby of mine ain't
as waterproof as it use to be.
• Time latest fad among the young
bucks now seems to be a craze for
those so-called leather coats. This
here fad, I believe, was started
by our "Country Gentleman," Mr.
"Mac" Dennis. Just how far he'll
be held responsible by St. Peter,
providin' he ever gets headed in
that direction, is moren I can say.
Hopkins Cotillion December 12th.

Realizing that two cotillion
clubs have proved unsatisfactory,
the Inter-fraternity Board, at a
meeting held November 13, passed
a resolution dissolving the Interfratern ity Cotillion Club and
requested tile Student Council
to permit the organization of
a cotillion club similar to the one
that was in existence two years
ago. The board of this club was
composed of one delegate from
each oftime seven fraternities and
one non-fraternity man.
It is hoped that the Student
Council will take prompt action
in this matter, as December 12 has •
been suggested as the date of the
opening dance.

Faculty Notes.
Owing to the large classes in
undergraduate mathematiCs this
year, Messrs. T. Dantzig, F. V.
Morley and B. H. Reddit have
been engaged to assist in the instruction.
Dr. Albright sailed from New
York for Naples on October 23.
From Naples he will proceed to
Alexandria and thence to Jaffa
and Jerusalem.
Dr. E.0. Hulburt, who returned
from France in July, after nearly
two years' service abroad in the
Research Division of the Signal
Corps, lilts enterecrupon his duties
as instructor in physics at the
University. Messrs. W.T. Wensel
and W. G. Brornbacher, formerly
of the Bureau of Standards, have
also been appointed instructors
in physics for the year 1919-20.
The Department of Psychology
has been granted the sum of$6,000
"for investigating the informational and educative effect upon
the public of certain motion pictures used in various campaigns
for the control, repression and
elimination of venereal diseases."
A memorial portrait of the late
Prof. Kirby Flower Smith will be
presented to the University on the
next Commemoration Day, February 22, 1920, by the former students and friends of the late Professor Smith. The committee in
charge of the presentation of the
portrait, which will be placed in
the main library, consists of Professors John C. French, John H.
Latane, Wilfred P. Mustard and
Robert B. Roulston. Dr. Roulston, the chairman, is still receiving subscriptions for the portrait.
Prof. C. K. Swartz spent a part
of the summer in a detailed study
of the stratigraphy of the carboniferous deposits in the vicinty of
Grantstille, Md., and in continuation of his monograph investigation on the carboniferous strata of
Maryland. He has in press at the
present time a report on the coal
fields of Maryland, which represents a refined, critical study of
the coal-bearing strata of this

state.

who told what the alumni were

Slips were distributed during

each man stated how much he

would make his payments. Each
man has the choice of paying all
at once or in five equal payments,
due on the first of February of
each year. To date, Silberstein
announced, the Senior Class had
promised $5,000, the Junior Class
$1,000, the SophOmoreClass $1,000
and the Freshman Class $7,500.
He urged every Hopkins man to
give something, no matter how
small, but to give all he could possibly afford.
The mass-meeting, which was
the largest ever held here—approximately five hundred men being present—was closed with
every man determined to do his
very best to keep up interest in
the erection of the dormitories,
and equally determined to give
every cent he could spare to the
fund.

With but three weeks remaining
before the first concert, the Musical Clubs have quickened their
stride and are swinging along at
double time. Thus far practices
have been held on Monday evenings, but beginning with Thursday the twentieth, rehearsals will
be held regularly on both Mondays and Thursdays at 8 P. M.
The attendance of the men who
hope to win a place on the clubs
for the concerts has been exceptionally good, due to the keen interest shown by all, as well as to
the realization that the next three
or four weeks will determine just
• who will represent the University
in the winter and spring concerts.
•
George Cattanach, the president
of the clubs, wishes to express his
gratification with the enthusiasm
showy and with the large number
of men who have indicated their
intention to win a place on one
of the clubs. Over fifty men signed
up, a good number from which to
.select the personnel proper, but
since the first two or three rehearsals a few men have dropped out.
These men are under classmen,
mostly freshmen, and the president cannot let pass the opportunity of warning them against an
indifferent and lax attitude, or a
"what's the use feeling." The man
who makes good in the clubs (and
it is not by any means an easy
job) is the man who, when an
under-classman sticks loyally to
the work, attends the rehearsals
regularly and gradually fits himself for a permanent place later
on. The freshman, who for one
reason or another, puts off this
work is greatly lessening his
chances of ever making the clubs,
for only the interested man is
wanted — the directors have no
time for any others.
The music being used this year
is the very best popular college
music obtainable. The Glee Club
songs are new at Hopkins, as well
as unique, and should prevent the
audience from leaving the concerts dry-eyed. The Instrumental
Club, with its wonderful assortment of mandoling, mandolas,
guitars, steel guitars, ukuleles and
banjo likes, will be a novelty this
year. In addition to the regular
"line," there will be several surprises for the audience, an expert
buck-and-wing dancer and a comic
song artist, a jazz orchestra, the
original interpretation of the Hawaiian native dances by the interpreter herself, and a Hawaiian
string trio.
, Harry Hartman, director of the
Glee Club, selected the 'Varsity
quartet after a series of try-outs.

A Hop in Hopkins Athletics.

Anyone who regards Mr. Kistler as the director of a puppet
show would receive a distinct revision of opinion were he to visit
Straus Field or observe the activities of his squads in other
quarters. Here, instead of bands
of disgruntled youths, passing
three hours every week to the
count of one, two, three, four, we
find squads of young, coming athletes engaged in practicing every
form of athletics. Football, lacrosse, basket-ball and soccer all
have their devotees.
The "pep" and enthusiasm of
these junior athletes cannot be emphasized enough. Seldom have
there been more closely or more
hotly contested games than the
two which have already been
played between the two Notball
sqnads. Iu'these games teamwork
and headwork was displayed on
both sides to such an extent that
the victorious team won by the
slender margin of 'six points in
both games. This is only one example of the interest shown by
these men. Basket-ball has a great
number of followers, in fact so
many that a league of eight teams
has been organized. Soccer, although started only Thursday,
promises, from the number of candidates, to be a great success, and
a huge *squad has already been
practicing lacrosse for some
weeks.
The greatest drawback to the
athletic success of Johns Hopkins has been the scarcity of ma-

terial. The organization of junior
athletics will undoubtedly be of
inestimable value in doing away
with this drawback. By thus
stimulating an interest in *athletics a far larger number of men
to pick from can be obtained and
many stars who were otherwise
"born to blush unseen" , will be
brought to light. Here is where
the future quarterback and ends,
lacrosse and basket-ball players
will be procured. Indeed much
promising material has already
been developed and it is thought
that within another year or so
the junior athletes will furnish, a
reliable reserve for the senior
teams.

Gentlemen of the jury, I trust
that most of you were keen-witted
enough to appreciate the rare bits
of satire and humor with which I
so generously sprinkled my last
article. With this trust in my
heart, I beg to submit for your
approval tile following clippings
gathered from here, there and
everywhere.
Yours in sport,
•

GEORGE.
To whom it may concern (and
unless I miss my guess, it will
concern a. goodly number): Dr.
Hulburt announced that all those
who have difficulties, minor or
otherwise, with their math problems may,if the worst collies to the
worst, hand in a blank paper, and
they will receive five points for
their nerve. Time eminent Doctor
failed to state just what he intended to do with the unspoiled sheets,
but I'll bet you a last year's almanac that in these days of high
prices he won't throw them away.
Dame Rumor has it that a little
incident worthy of publicity was
enacted lately, with our dearly beloved Capt. Ehner Jones playing
the leading lady. Everybody, no
doubt, has noticed the hat of
emerald lino that has been seen
liii 111mg around the University
with Elmer underneath of it.
Well, Elmer was taking this ancient and honorable chapeau out
for a walk on the boulevard the
other day, when for some unknown reason a little maid who
was strolling by the wayside was
heard to remark: "Oh, look,
Nursie, is that the Kaiser?" How
about it, Elmer, do I get that
hat?—that old 'derby of mine ain't
as waterproof as it use to be.
• Time latest fad among the young
bucks now seems to be a craze for
those so-called leather coats. This
here fad, I believe, was started
by our "Country Gentleman," Mr.
"Mac" Dennis. Just how far he'll
be held responsible by St. Peter,
providin' he ever gets headed in
that direction, is moren I can say.
Hopkins Cotillion December 12th.

Realizing that two cotillion
clubs have proved unsatisfactory,
the Inter-fraternity Board, at a
meeting held November 13, passed
a resolution dissolving the Interfratern ity Cotillion Club and
requested tile Student Council
to permit the organization of
a cotillion club similar to the one
that was in existence two years
ago. The board of this club was
composed of one delegate from
each oftime seven fraternities and
one non-fraternity man.
It is hoped that the Student
Council will take prompt action
in this matter, as December 12 has •
been suggested as the date of the
opening dance.

Faculty Notes.
Owing to the large classes in
undergraduate mathematiCs this
year, Messrs. T. Dantzig, F. V.
Morley and B. H. Reddit have
been engaged to assist in the instruction.
Dr. Albright sailed from New
York for Naples on October 23.
From Naples he will proceed to
Alexandria and thence to Jaffa
and Jerusalem.
Dr. E.0. Hulburt, who returned
from France in July, after nearly
two years' service abroad in the
Research Division of the Signal
Corps, lilts enterecrupon his duties
as instructor in physics at the
University. Messrs. W.T. Wensel
and W. G. Brornbacher, formerly
of the Bureau of Standards, have
also been appointed instructors
in physics for the year 1919-20.
The Department of Psychology
has been granted the sum of$6,000
"for investigating the informational and educative effect upon
the public of certain motion pictures used in various campaigns
for the control, repression and
elimination of venereal diseases."
A memorial portrait of the late
Prof. Kirby Flower Smith will be
presented to the University on the
next Commemoration Day, February 22, 1920, by the former students and friends of the late Professor Smith. The committee in
charge of the presentation of the
portrait, which will be placed in
the main library, consists of Professors John C. French, John H.
Latane, Wilfred P. Mustard and
Robert B. Roulston. Dr. Roulston, the chairman, is still receiving subscriptions for the portrait.
Prof. C. K. Swartz spent a part
of the summer in a detailed study
of the stratigraphy of the carboniferous deposits in the vicinty of
Grantstille, Md., and in continuation of his monograph investigation on the carboniferous strata of
Maryland. He has in press at the
present time a report on the coal
fields of Maryland, which represents a refined, critical study of
the coal-bearing strata of this

state.

who told what the alumni were
doing in the manner of raising
funds and how the undergraduates
could help. He emphasized, as
Mr. Griswold had done, that this
was to be a Hopkins memorial in
every sense of the word and that
it was up to the student body to
"come across" with a substantial
amount, so that they would have
a worthy share in providing the
memorial.
Slips were distributed during
the course of the meeting on which
each man stated how much he
would give and in what way he
would make his payments. Each
man has the choice of paying all
at once or in five equal payments,
due on the first of February of
each year. To date, Silberstein
announced, the Senior Class had
promised $5,000, the Junior Class
$1,000, the SophOmoreClass $1,000
and the Freshman Class $7,500.
He urged every Hopkins man to
give something, no matter how
small, but to give all he could possibly afford.
The mass-meeting, which was
the largest ever held here—approximately five hundred men being present—was closed with
every man determined to do his
very best to keep up interest in
the erection of the dormitories,
and equally determined to give
every cent he could spare to the
fund.
